Fields.DialogueText: Boiky, are you out here?
Chert! Kapitan, byt' ostorozhen!
Whoa!
Kapitan, I've never seen such a swift dodge! You must teach that to the rest of the crew.

Fields.MenuText: I think an overview of safety regulations would be more useful.
Here's your hacksaw. Try to hold on to it this time.
Whatever you're doing, I hope it's worth nearly hospitalizing me.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course! Please allow me to guest lecture. The crew will never have learned more!
Da, count on it!
Anything worth doing is worth bleeding for, nyet?
What are you doing, anyway?
Call it surgery, Kapitan. That last storm really put a strain on my top deck. I'm practically bursting at the weld seams!
That doesn't... Hurt?
Not with enough sushki, it doesn't! Would you like one? It's like a better doughnut!
I'm going to have to pass. Can you get that fixed quickly? There's been heavy Morgana activity reported nearby.
Oh, let them come! The Rusalki are too quick to judge a ship by her hull.
Her damaged hull.
The devil is in the details, Kapitan, and I do not believe in devils!
That's exactly why I--
Why, look! Here comes another devil for me to disbelieve in.
@BATTLE
Rusalka, tvoya mat' byla parusnaya lodka!
That's... Some battle cry.
It doesn't matter if her mother was really a sailboat. Now it falls to her to deny it!
@BATTLE
Grrr... Not again!
Still having problems with the guns?
I write to Command, and they tell me there is only so much their lend-lease can provide. I write to Admiral Kuznetsov himself, and he says "later". All while my guns overheat!

Fields.MenuText: Well, complaining won't help at all.
You've been making the best of a bad situation, at least.
That's the best your country can do for you? That's infuriating!

Fields.DialogueText: Nyet, nyet... But, it's good to get it out of my system.
Thank you, Kapitan! Isn't that the essence of history?
Da, but some of mankind's greatest works are born from fury!
I will simply have to improvise. I'm not replacing another gun barrel until they last for more than one engagement!
Improvise how and with what?
Well, would you look at that? It seems my poor B-13s are in need of repairs already. I will have to figure something out.
You don't know.
Not yet, Kapitan, and isn't that what makes war fun?
I don't dare ask.
Chto ne tak? It's just a rubber band.
It's stretched all the way across the bow!
If you're shooting what I'm shooting, you've got to go big!
We have guns for the Morganas, Boiky.
Nyet, nyet, nyet, I am not talking about our targets. I'm talking about our ammunition!
I'm going to regret asking, but what ammunition are you talking about?
Ah! There it is now.
Tell me that's not--
I've got to do something with all those spent gun barrels, ne tak li?

Fields.MenuText: This is either the most efficient idea I've seen, or the worst. Maybe both.
I'm putting a stop to this right now. It's a waste of materiel.
You can't expect this to work.

Fields.DialogueText: History will vindicate it, Kapitan!
We won't know until we try, Kapitan!
Something will happen, and that's what's important!
Khorosho, crew! You've done your duty. Now, watch and learn...
Boiky, put that down at once!
Too late, Kapitan! Like a bow's string, the rubber band must be released once drawn.
Boiky--
Bozhe moi, look at it go!
Very funny. Now ready your real weapons.
@BATTLE
We've had the most interesting cable from Admiral Kuznetsov.
Ooh! What's it say, what's it say, what's it say?
Let's see... "While the Commissariat appreciate your zeal in defense of the Motherland, we must insist that you dispose of materiel properly." Paraphrased, but you get the gist.
But... it worked!
A five-and-a-half-ton gun barrel to the face usually will, but it's too dangerous.
I thought that was the idea.
Too dangerous for our side. One slip and that barrel could go flying into our ships.
The solution is simple, Kapitan! I--
"Don't slip" doesn't count as a solution.
Well, that's just a waste. What am I to do with all my strength?

Fields.MenuText: Use your regular slingshot.
Everything the crew does, but better.
You'll think of something.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, Kapitan, but it's just so small! I've gone to space, and you give me a paper airplane!
Just think of me as the first among equals!
That's so boring!
You let me worry about your guns, and do what you do best.
Everything?
Specifically, against these Morganas.
@BATTLE
Where did you say-- Oh. Right. Here she is.
Zzz... Etot marsh nye smolkal na perronakh... Zzz...
Well, looks like Boiky's off to the scrapyard. It's been a good run...
When there is state there can be no freedom! Don't do it! I'm up! I'm up!
I shouldn't be this used to finding you like this.
Chert! Where did I leave off?
Brushing your teeth, apparently.
Oh, this? The bulkheads were looking a little grimy, so I took some liberties.

Fields.MenuText: Liberties? This is a self-imposed punishment.
Well, you're... They're... Looking shinier already.
I suppose it's better than launching pieces of yourself into the ocean.

Fields.DialogueText: Punishment is not punishment that improves the body!
Spasibo! There is no shiny that cannot be shinier...
Perhaps we can agree that it is different.
Now may I ask why?
I'm in a constant state of repair, Kapitan. Not a day goes by that I'm not patching something up!
That, and I'm not allowed to make my own weapons anymore.
Trust me, our allies are grateful. I'm grateful.
Well, back at it, I suppose.
That really won't be necessary. You're in fine shape as it is.
I'm talking about the nearby Morganas! Hold this, Kapitan, there's a battle to fight!
Do Belles even need toothbrushes?
@BATTLE
Bozhe moi, but I could eat a whale!
Hard at work as always.
The very hardest! I must have cleaned every surface, double-counted the munitions, cooked the crew's meals for the rest of the week...
Is that why there are so many meringues in the galley?
Zefirs, Kapitan! There's an important difference.

Fields.MenuText: They're just egg whites and sugar.
I'll take your word for it.
I really couldn't care less.

Fields.DialogueText: More than that! Can't forget the apple puree!
You don't have to! I made a batch just for you.
Well, more for me, I suppose.
One of these days you're going to run out of things to clean.
Never! Like I told you, there is no shiny that cannot be shinier.
There's only so much you can do with a toothbrush and water.
That's where fire comes in!
No. No, it is not.
You doubt the cleansing power of fire?
I don't. That's why I... Look, let's just find you something to shoot at.
Da, pozhaluysta!
@BATTLE
Okay, Boiky, I've made an executive decision.
I swear this charlotte was just sitting there, Kapitan!
Forget the desserts. I've been in communication with Command about your... hobbies.
I prefer to think of them as vital shorings-up for the revolution!
Even so, there are better ways for you to be helpful.
Blowing up more Morganas?
Got it in one. Command's considering sending you on more dangerous missions.
Oh, Kapitan, thank you! You won't regret it!

Fields.MenuText: I hope not. I'm pulling a lot of strings for you.
I didn't think I would. Nobody else has your enthusiasm.
We've got to point you at something.

Fields.DialogueText: I will weave them into a glorious tapestry of destruction!
We Belles are not truly alive if we do not kill! Ask any of the German destroyers, fascists though they are...
The best weapon pulls its own trigger, I like to say!
I'm glad we could come to an understanding. That being said, is there anything I need to know about first?
Da! I was just about to spend the day repainting, but I'll set it aside until the hunt slows down.
Good. Nothing to worry about then.
Indeed! Just let me disarm the charges I set on the paint cans.
On second thought, just throw those at the Morganas... Off the record.
@BATTLE
So, where would Command have us shoot first?
It's not so much a where as a what. Longer patrols means more opportunities for engagement.
Just what I needed!
Yes. Having said that, there is the matter of your cruising range...
4,890 kilometers, ser!
Except when you've been eating poorly. That is to say, always.
Ne volnuytes'. You need to keep your energy up to be as productive as I am. Sugar may not be the best way, but it is certainly the tastiest.

Fields.MenuText: We are not basing our tactics on your diet. Improve it.
The first time you pass out mid-battle is the last time you eat sweets.
I hope you brought enough for everyone.

Fields.DialogueText: Trust me, Kapitan, the fuel the Motherland was giving me before the Rusalki was worse.
Agreed! I'm glad I can count on you to wake me up.
Everyone in our crew, or every one of our allies? Because I've got quite the stash!
I know what happened the last time I cut you off. Just... eat some fruit each day?
Chocolate-covered prunes don't count?
I wonder if Command know what they've gotten themselves into.
Perhaps not. We must make sure they smell smoke from their mountains!
Always nice to have a goal.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
There she is now, Kapitan. Just cruising along, so smug you can taste it...
Are you sure that's not your chocolate?
Chocolate decadence and Morgana decadence are two very different things!
Can ghosts really be decadent?
Are they not obsessed with their appearance?
They're certainly good at intimidation, but--
Do they not seek to overthrow the very unity of mankind for personal gain?

Fields.MenuText: Well, we don't really know what they're after.

Fields.DialogueText: And besides, they look like rotting corpses anyway. Of course they're decadent!
That's not exactly what "decadent" means.
Decadent. Decaying. A distinction devoid of difference.
Stop that.
Da!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: You have a point.
Maybe they eat a disagreeable diet, and this is the result.

Fields.DialogueText: I have many good points, if only more people would listen!
I don't like your implication, Kapitan.
Do they even think? Or are they just animals?
Ha! That was only the opening salvo, you filthy Rusalki!
Steady, Boiky.
The waves are not steady, and nor should we be!
@BATTLE
All right, the shooting's over. You can come down now.
Da! Byt' ostorozhen!
I never thought I'd say this, but the crew are really enjoying these missions.
They should! Any chance to strike down one's enemies is a blessing.
Your excitement really is infectious. I want you to know that.
Then mission accomplished!
Having said that... why do you use a slingshot?
It's the simplest of weapons! Only two moving parts to worry about. I leave the gunfire to the engineers and soldiers.
I can understand that, but where do you get your mines? You never seem to run out.
I just reach into my pockets, and there they are. Doesn't everyone?

Fields.MenuText: No, we don't.
That raises several more questions.
If only...

Fields.DialogueText: Well, that's no problem. I'll just need to shoot faster!
Why ask and ask when you can just watch and laugh?
One day, Kapitan, we will have more guns than we'll know what to do with! Won't it be glorious?
But, even so, how can you possibly--
Don't think about it too hard, Kapitan. When will you learn to sit back and watch the explosions?
Kapitan, these Morganas just keep coming!
That's what we signed up for. Are you ready?
I was built ready!
@BATTLE
Can we find more like them?
We shouldn't have any trouble. There's supposed to be a storm brewing in the Skagerrak, and it's Morgana in origin.
Break out of the Baltic and scatter the Rusalki across the waves of the North Sea! I like it.
Good. We'll be cooperating closely with Kriegsmarine ships, and--
Prosti, Kapitan, I thought you said "Kriegsmarine."
Don't start. We're all in this together.
You're right, but... Ooh, those cowardly Nazis! You know I don't like cleaning up for the Germans.

Fields.MenuText: Peace on the seas. That's all we need to know.
Blame the Morganas. They tend to be the ones picking the battles.
You do remember that I'm German?

Fields.DialogueText: A peace kept by fascists is no peace at all.
I wish they'd just... Pick them closer to home.
Very funny, Kapitan.
I need to know that I can trust you to follow Command's orders. No Nazi turkey shoots.
You have my word, but what will I destroy when I'm annoyed?
Anything but our ships.
Anything?
That was a poor choice of words...
Are we there yet?
No.
Are we there yet?
No.
Are we there yet?
I'm tempted to turn you around and have you mothballed in Riga.
It's feels like it's been so long since our last Rusalki. Days, at least!
What do you want me to do about it?
Find me something to shoot at! At this rate, the Rusalki will bore me to death.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe they'll assign me to a Belle with a longer fuse.
How do we know that's not their plan?
There must be something you haven't cleaned yet.

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitan! You know you don't mean that. What about the fun we have?
Bozhe moi... You may be right! I've got to find something to do immediately!
I swear I've been over every inch of myself, even the boilers... I'd have to do the crew's laundry. I hate doing laundry!
Maybe we'll get lucky and find--
*BOOM*
Wish granted.
@BATTLE
We're based in Copenhagen for now.
Czar Alexander got to Paris.
What was that?
Nichego, Kapitan! Just thinking out loud.
Anyway, I'm surprised at you, Boiky. You've been working nonstop since we left for Denmark.
Just doing my duty for the Motherland!
In fact, I don't think I've seen you sleep for weeks.
You learn to do without. We Belles have a knack for it!
Even after I had you cut down on sweets... I thought sugar kept you awake.
It does, but I've found a way around it! That French submarine I get my sweets from was more than happy to part with--
Coffee.
How'd you guess?
I hadn't noticed the smell until now. That, and you're vibrating.
Kapitan, you really should calm down. Did you know you're shaking?

Fields.MenuText: Do you even know where your contact gets her wares?
I hope this won't affect your aim.
If it's not one addiction, it's another...

Fields.DialogueText: She told me she ran an expansive charity, or was it an expensive chicanery? I'm not entirely sure what that means.
I've corrected for worse, believe me!
Nonsense! I can stop any time... Later.
I'm curious. Surely your coffee wasn't free. What did you trade for it?
All my pay that hasn't been going to sweets!
You're oddly proud of that.
Consider it an investment in the Motherland's fiercest warrior! Those Rusalki certainly will.
Fiercest or poorest...?
@BATTLE
Come and join me by the fire, Kapitan!
What did I tell you about building fires on deck?
I know, but I thought the occasion called for it. Pass me the parcel there, the fire's getting low.
More bourgeois literature?
You might say that.
Boiky, this one's signed from one of the German Belles.
Isn't it?
There are a few others here as well. You've been writing to the German Belles?
I've been writing back, but what am I supposed to do with these welcome letters? The welcome is over.

Fields.MenuText: Whatever you like, I suppose.
At least something more respectful.
An apology, for a start.

Fields.DialogueText: Khorosho. If you'll just hand those back to me...
They are just words. Actions carry weight. Here is one.
You think they wouldn't do the same in my shoes?
It sounds to me like the German Belles are excited to work with you. Why, this one's even--
You've never played poker with her. I've heard the stories. She's an expert bluffer... Rather like her Führer.
Just give them a chance. They're on your side.
As long as there are Rusalki to fight.
Then find more Morganas.
*ALARM*
Already done. I'm going to need another cup of coffee...
And put out that fire!
Make it two.
@BATTLE
Will you look at that shell fly!
Would that I could. Human eyesight's not quite up to it.
Hmph. Not like I couldn't shoot faster. Those Type-1936s are such prima donnas.
Prove it.
Da, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
I don't know about you, but I'd call that engagement a success.
Care for some charlotte?
I'm not really hungry. Did you hear what I said?
I did. I also know that you don't talk with your mouth full.

Fields.MenuText: Very funny. As I was saying...
Maybe I will have some after all. You're in no mood for a debriefing.
This has to stop. You're acting childish.

Fields.DialogueText: I know what you were going to say.
Take it all. I need to leave room for the blini.
I'm barely three! I'm allowed.
You and the German Belles worked well together. I don't care what you say about them.
How am I supposed to stand it? They oppose everything I'm fighting for!
Survival?
Oh, you're no help! Them and their obsession with their "Thousand-Year Reich..."
Can they help it if they were built that way? What must they be saying about you?
Exactly why I'm writing back to them. If they spend their time talking to me, they will have none for their drivel!
Better than shooting them, I suppose.
Kapitan, have you seen any of the radiomen?
In the interest of operational security, no.
Upryamyy! What is that supposed to mean?
Boiky, you were up at three in the morning last night singing folk songs. Nobody needs that.
But, I don't have time during the day to practice!
Who, exactly, is your intended audience?
It can't be the Morganas. You don't have the patience for anything but shooting during an engagement, and it can't be the crew. You already have their undivided attention.
You drop one gun barrel during an inspection...
So, I'll ask again...
Well, you told me I can't shoot at the German Belles. You never said anything about keeping them awake.
That right there is why I've restricted us to flags for the day.
Besides, Miss You-Know-Who wouldn't stop singing the Horst Wessel song yesterday.
I'll solve both your problems. Keep away from the radio room.
Back to the drawing board, then!
If you're going to annoy anyone to death, try these Morganas. They don't take kindly to mines.
@BATTLE
Otlichno! Excellent shot. Right, Klemperer, Vizzini, take a break. You've both earned it!
Shooting practice?
Every day, Kapitan, until they can hit with a pistol what I can't with a slingshot!
The German and Italian crew members don't bother you?
Nyet. Why would they?
You've spent this whole tour railing against their countries and their Belles.
People are not their countries! I may hate Hitler and Mussolini, but they are not here. Sometimes working-class people just find themselves on the wrong side.

Fields.MenuText: What about the Nazi Belles?
I wonder if every side doesn't feel that way.
The side that isn't yours.

Fields.DialogueText: They can't help the way they were built, but they are built fascist nonetheless.
So, why hash it out before the smoke clears?
We can't all be at the forefront of a revolution, Kapitan! That's what I'm for.
Interesting. Well, if you can get along with the non-Soviet soldiers, you can at least tolerate their Belles.
I will try to treat them as I would anyone else, Kapitan.
Meaning?
They must get out of the way when I shoot.
That's not what tolerance is.
Our crew seems to tolerate it!
Do we need to have another talk about friendly fire?
Not if there are enough Rusalki to shoot at! Here they are now...
@BATTLE
Kapitan, it's Radioman Alighieri!
What did I say about annoying the German Belles?
Nyet, Kapitan, it's serious! He's deathly ill!
I'll have a replacement in for him. He's in the infirmary?
Da! We're keeping an eye on him until we know what it is.
What do you mean, "until we know what it is"? What's happened to him?
We thought it was just some kind of pneumonia, but he keeps waking up screaming! Like from a nightmare...

Fields.MenuText: Keep a close eye on him. We don't know what state his mind's in.
We'll keep him sedated. No need to strain morale.
The quicker he's back on land, the better.

Fields.DialogueText: You speak my thoughts, Kapitan! Superstition isn't the vice it used to be.
You can count on me, Kapitan!
But, what if he says something? What if he's seen something in his dreams?
You just do what needs to be done. This can't affect the crew's performance.
Da! First thing I will do is--
Steer clear of Alighieri.
Wait... Do you hear that? Is that him?
Kapitan, it means there are Rusalki nearby!
Don't even start. It's just a coincidence.
@BATTLE
@BATTLE
All right, I think that's all for today's report. Any development with our radioman?
Still delirious. I've been trying to help how I can.
How's that?
You know how I never run out of mines?

Fields.MenuText: I try not to think about it too hard.
How do you do that, again?
It's a sickness. You can't blow up a sickness.

Fields.DialogueText: There are more important things for a kapitan to worry about, anyway!
Just leave the details to me, Kapitan. You take care of the logistics.
One of a few things you can't solve with fire... Yet.
Anyway, I've given some to the crew to personalize. A gift basket might be just the thing our comrade needs to cheer up!
A gift basket full of little mines.
Painted just like Easter eggs! Won't it be sweet?
It's certainly unique, but maybe you're on to something. It's nice to have people thinking of you.
V samom dele! Oh, speaking of Easter eggs, there's this other tradition where you tap them together to see which--
*No.*
Oh, Kapitan! I'm obviously not talking about the live ones.
Morgana forces, closing range. All hands to battle stations!
Good news, Boiky!
Dire news, Kapitan!
You first. What's that box you've got there?
See that terrible black spider? It is Nazi trickery! Imagine-- fascist snakes using our mail against us!
Give that to me. That's what I was going to tell you about.
Kakiye? Kapitan, what on earth can you--
I put in a request to Command about Alighieri's condition, and an institute in Frankfurt got back to us first. Ever heard of sulfa?
That drug that cures everything?
Well, not everything. But, from what I've been hearing, his illness sounds less like Morgana magic and more like pneumonia. Sulfa ought to help.
You'd let our man put some fascist snake oil in his body?

Fields.MenuText: He's Italian. By your logic, he'll be fine.
It's science, Boiky. Surely your country didn't purge every intellectual.
I'm trying to save him, and so are the Germans.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm... I suppose that makes sense.
That's what the Americans call a "low blow", Kapitan.
So am I! My way just involves more mines.
You focus on the fight, Boiky, and let me do the thinking. You might be surprised.
I don't have to like it, but maybe some gunfire will help me try.
@BATTLE
Well, look who's up and about, eh, Boiky?
I can hardly believe it, and I was the first to see him!
Alighieri will be back at his post within the week. I understand you've been helping around the infirmary.
I knew there was something I hadn't cleaned. Disinfecting things is so much fun!
Anything else you'd like to add?
Da. I suppose you were right about the sulfa.
And?
And, Frankfurt's heart was in the right place. I suppose I should appreciate their contribution.

Fields.MenuText: That's the right attitude to have.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, we don't have to agree on all matters to solve a single problem, do we? The fascists have proved that.
I'm surprised, Boiky. That's humble coming from you.
Spasibo, Kapitan.
Let's see if we can't help them. It looks like our friends are coming under fire.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Oh no! Those spies are earning your trust before they ultimately betray you, Boiky!
Beware of Greeks bearing gifts...

Fields.DialogueText: I do not understand. They are not Greek...
Forget it, Boiky. Juste a bad joke. I'm glad you are getting along.
What?! Do you think so? Oh...
Command's finally given the order, Boiky. Skagerrak needs to be cleared.
We're finally opening the Sound again! We've been cut off for too long from the rest of the world.
Absolutely. They want us to help lead the charge.
They need only point me toward danger!
I'm glad you're up to it. Are your guns ready?
As they'll ever be. I've been over every inch of them, but there's only so much I can do with flawed machinery.
Your "only so much" goes a long way.
Kapitan, I'm touched! You really--
What? What is it?
Kapitan, here they come!
@BATTLE
Damage report, Boiky.
Blew out some of the B-13s, as usual. But, other than some bruises... it feels typical. Nothing I cannot deal with.
Good. A sneak attack like that doesn't always go so well.
It's a good thing the Germans happened to be on patrol. The Rusalki were being followed from the beginning.

Fields.MenuText: Allies can come from unlikely places.
I'm glad you're all right. We can't afford to lose you.
I think you owe our friends some thanks.

Fields.DialogueText: If you say so.
The revolution would find another, but I would hate to cut my fun short!
Isn't my shooting thanks enough?
You and the German Belles should talk. You might see eye to eye on more than you think, even if it's just tactics.
You may have a point, Kapitan, but I will keep my slingshot close at hand when speaking with them.
I'm back from our tea.
You and the German Belle?
She was... maddening.
What did you talk about?
The weather, to start, and that turned into tactics, and then the Rusalki, and then she asked about why I call them that, and then...
You brought up communism.
She was so... Ooh! Why does she have to be so nice!?

Fields.MenuText: Not everyone's as spirited as you are.
Conversations aren't always ideological battles.
Sounds like you've made a friend.

Fields.DialogueText: She's so ridiculously quiet! How can anyone stand it?
But, where is the fun in that?
An... acquaintance. I still have my doubts.
So, it was a success.
She did like my charlotte, and we talked gun maintenance.
I wondered what kept you for three hours.
Three!? Chert, what time is it?
Time for you to put that gun talk to good use. Morganas inbound.
@BATTLE
Can you smell that, Kapitan?
There's something about the North Sea that you can't help but appreciate.
We fought and bled for it! That makes our arrival all the sweeter.
Having made some friends along the way doesn't hurt.
Don't ruin the moment! I've gone for some time without thinking about it.
Oh, come on. Don't think I don't know what you've been spending your time on lately.
I... I don't know what you're talking about!

Fields.MenuText: I couldn't see my face in your bulkhead. You've been cleaning less often.
There's no shame in talking with your ideological enemies.
How has your new friend been lately?

Fields.DialogueText: Eto pravda? I must fix this at once! Do not tell me which bulkhead, I will swab them all!
But we are like bears and bees! We are built to destroy each other.
Just the other day she made this delicious-- Nyet, nevazhno!
Don't be so embarrassed. You're all about finding common ground. You just never thought you'd find it with a fascist.
A fascist that makes delicious apple strudel, I must admit.
If I didn't know better, I'd say you were courting her.
Do not joke about that, Kapitan! I would sooner eat my own mines!
Here are Morganas to feed them to instead. Give my regards to your friend.
Idi k chertu!
@BATTLE
Zzz... Utro krasit nezhnym svetom ... Zzz... Steny drevnego Kremlia...
Still tired from the last battle?
One man with a gun can control a hundred without one! Izvinite, Kapitan!
Is this why the crew has been eating out on deck today?
Da! I have been cooking up a storm to celebrate our victory in Skagerrak.
I hope you didn't leave anything on a stove before you passed out.
Nikogda! My kitchen discipline is second only to my trigger discipline.

Fields.MenuText: That doesn't inspire a lot of confidence.
Good. I guess you're more careful than I give you credit for.
So, what are we making?

Fields.DialogueText: You're certainly vigilant, Kapitan. I have to commend that in you!
When death and cakes are on the line, I spare no precaution!
A little bit of everything, Kapitan!
Today I thought I'd give back to the crew and the fleet. A little feast to raise the spirits. Our glorious campaign has only begun!
A feast consisting of seven courses of dessert, by the looks of it.
I made plenty for every crewmember. The hardest part is tasting it all!
Do you mind if I try some of this blini? It looks--
